title: Role
data:
**[English]()**

 • [한국어](/wiki/Role/ko "Role/ko")

When starting *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*, the game asks for the **role** you want to play, with the option of letting the game randomly pick one. You can also set the role in your [nethackrc](/wiki/Nethackrc "Nethackrc") file, or specify it on the command line with the -p option.

Each role begins with different starting equipment and different levels of mastery in weapons. Intrinsics that are gained when leveling up (such as a [Ranger](/wiki/Ranger "Ranger")'s intrinsic stealth) and conducts (such as the [Monk](/wiki/Monk "Monk")'s vegetarian conducts) also vary with each role. Experienced players often attempt to ascend all thirteen roles. Some roles are considered more [difficult](/wiki/Role_difficulty "Role difficulty") to ascend than others. See [role difficulty](/wiki/Role_difficulty "Role difficulty") for more details.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Role table by starting attributes and intrinsics](#Role_table_by_starting_attributes_and_intrinsics)

- [2 Role table by alignment and race](#Role_table_by_alignment_and_race)

- [3 Variants](#Variants)

  - [3.1 SLASH'EM Role table by alignment and race](#SLASH.27EM_Role_table_by_alignment_and_race)
  - [3.2 dNethack Role table by alignment and race](#dNethack_Role_table_by_alignment_and_race)

- [4 See also](#See_also)

- [5 Other games](#Other_games)

- [6 References](#References)

## Role table by starting attributes and intrinsics

The following contains the mean and [standard deviation](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/standard_deviation "wikipedia:standard deviation") of the starting [attributes](/wiki/Attribute "Attribute"); the initial intrinsics; and the intrinsics gained at specific [experience levels](/wiki/Experience_level "Experience level"), for various roles played as [humans](/wiki/Human_\(starting_race\) "Human (starting race)"). The means and standard deviations were found by simulation; the simulation source code can found on the talk page.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1) Note that non-human races may have different mean attributes due to attribute maximums, especially if the maximum for an attribute is less than approximately one or two standard deviations above the human mean.

|                                                   | Str           | Dex        | Con        | Int        | Wis        | Cha        | Initial intrinsics                   | Gained intrinsics                                                                                                                                                 |
| ------------------------------------------------- | ------------- | ---------- | ---------- | ---------- | ---------- | ---------- | ------------------------------------ | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| [Archeologist](/wiki/Archeologist "Archeologist") | 12.79±2.15    | 9.78±1.63  | 12.50±2.10 | 15.34±1.86 | 15.34±1.86 | 9.51±1.57  | speed, stealth                       | XL 10: searching                                                                                                                                                  |
| [Barbarian](/wiki/Barbarian "Barbarian")          | 18/00.89±1.34 | 16.72±1.01 | 17.69±0.59 | 7.60±0.87  | 7.69±0.91  | 6.60±0.87  | poison resistance                    | XL 7: speed, XL 15: stealth                                                                                                                                       |
| [Cave(wo)man](/wiki/Caveman "Caveman")            | 18/01.61±2.48 | 13.19±2.16 | 16.43±1.76 | 8.90±1.40  | 9.21±1.49  | 7.90±1.40  |                                      | XL 7: speed, XL 15: warning                                                                                                                                       |
| [Healer](/wiki/Healer "Healer")                   | 9.31±1.46     | 9.17±1.42  | 14.55±1.63 | 9.87±1.57  | 15.77±1.40 | 16.56±0.73 | poison resistance                    | XL 15: warning                                                                                                                                                    |
| [Knight](/wiki/Knight "Knight")                   | 14.95±1.24    | 8.66±0.89  | 11.27±1.10 | 7.97±1.01  | 14.96±0.97 | 17.43±0.53 |                                      | XL 7: speed                                                                                                                                                       |
| [Monk](/wiki/Monk "Monk")                         | 17.34±2.37    | 13.63±2.10 | 11.26±1.95 | 9.86±1.66  | 13.63±2.10 | 9.57±1.59  | see invisible sleep resistance speed | XL 3: poison resistance XL 5: stealth XL 7: warning XL 9: searching XL 11: fire resistance XL 13: cold resistance XL 15: shock resistance XL 17: teleport control |
| [Priest(ess)](/wiki/Priest "Priest")              | 12.21±2.07    | 11.89±2.01 | 13.47±2.16 | 10.28±1.74 | 17.44±1.08 | 9.95±1.67  |                                      | XL 15: warning, XL 20: fire resistance                                                                                                                            |
| [Ranger](/wiki/Ranger "Ranger")                   | 15.22±1.32    | 10.45±1.17 | 14.44±1.14 | 13.75±0.93 | 13.75±0.93 | 7.68±0.91  | searching                            | XL 7: stealth, XL 15: see invisible                                                                                                                               |
| [Rogue](/wiki/Rogue "Rogue")                      | 14.10±2.29    | 17.52±1.00 | 13.72±2.18 | 10.41±1.77 | 10.41±1.77 | 9.07±1.70  | stealth                              | XL 10: searching                                                                                                                                                  |
| [Samurai](/wiki/Samurai "Samurai")                | 15.90±1.94    | 15.54±1.75 | 17.91±0.32 | 9.94±1.37  | 8.56±1.27  | 7.37±1.20  | speed                                | XL 15: stealth                                                                                                                                                    |
| [Tourist](/wiki/Tourist "Tourist")                | 11.60±1.99    | 11.31±1.94 | 15.28±2.10 | 12.89±1.65 | 8.89±1.66  | 15.29±1.86 |                                      | XL 10: searching, XL 20: poison resistance                                                                                                                        |
| [Valkyrie](/wiki/Valkyrie "Valkyrie")             | 18/00.86±2.34 | 12.72±2.08 | 17.11±1.32 | 8.75±1.35  | 9.04±1.43  | 8.76±1.35  | cold resistance, stealth             | XL 7: speed                                                                                                                                                       |
| [Wizard](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard")                   | 10.60±1.80    | 13.48±2.15 | 13.47±2.15 | 17.44±1.07 | 10.28±1.74 | 9.96±1.67  |                                      | XL 8: teleport at will if wizard has [teleportitis](/wiki/Teleportitis "Teleportitis") XL 15: warning XL 17: teleport control                                     |

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

These numbers are slightly different because an off-by-one error which slightly biased strength over charisma was fixed in [this commit](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/7d140c6a70a11142d001526cdccc484132a30a59).

Also, some role intrinsics have changed, since [commit 075c2832](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/075c2832a1145ff3dc0049f2cfa6f3b86352179e):

- Archeologists now start with searching, get stealth at XL 5, and speed at XL 10.
- Valkyries get stealth at XL 3.

## See also

- [Role difficulty](/wiki/Role_difficulty "Role difficulty")

## Other games

Some other games, such as *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")* use the word "class", and *[MapleStory](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MapleStory "wikipedia:MapleStory")* and *[Final Fantasy](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Final_Fantasy "wikipedia:Final Fantasy")*, for example, use "job", while NetHack always calls them roles.

html:
Role

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
English

 • 한국어

When starting NetHack, the game asks for the role you want to play, with the option of letting the game randomly pick one. You can also set the role in your nethackrc file, or specify it on the command line with the -p option.

Each role begins with different starting equipment and different levels of mastery in weapons. Intrinsics that are gained when leveling up (such as a Ranger's intrinsic stealth) and conducts (such as the Monk's vegetarian conducts) also vary with each role. Experienced players often attempt to ascend all thirteen roles. Some roles are considered more difficult to ascend than others. See role difficulty for more details.

Contents

  • 1 Role table by starting attributes and intrinsics
  • 2 Role table by alignment and race
  • 3 Variants
    • 3.1 SLASH'EM Role table by alignment and race
    • 3.2 dNethack Role table by alignment and race
  • 4 See also
  • 5 Other games
  • 6 References

Role table by starting attributes and intrinsics

The following contains the mean and standard deviation of the starting attributes; the initial intrinsics; and the intrinsics gained at specific experience levels, for various roles played as humans. The means and standard deviations were found by simulation; the simulation source code can found on the talk page.[1] Note that non-human races may have different mean attributes due to attribute maximums, especially if the maximum for an attribute is less than approximately one or two standard deviations above the human mean.

Str Dex Con Int Wis Cha Initial intrinsics Gained intrinsics
Archeologist 12.79±2.15 9.78±1.63 12.50±2.10 15.34±1.86 15.34±1.86 9.51±1.57 speed, stealth XL 10: searching
Barbarian 18/00.89±1.34 16.72±1.01 17.69±0.59 7.60±0.87 7.69±0.91 6.60±0.87 poison resistance XL 7: speed, XL 15: stealth

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (NetHack 3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

These numbers are slightly different because an off-by-one error which slightly biased strength over charisma was fixed in this commit.

Also, some role intrinsics have changed, since commit 075c2832:

  • Archeologists now start with searching, get stealth at XL 5, and speed at XL 10.
  • Valkyries get stealth at XL 3.

Role table by alignment and race

The following role, race, and alignment combinations are permitted upon character creation.[2]

See also

  • Role difficulty

Other games

Some other games, such as Dungeons & Dragons use the word "class", and MapleStory and Final Fantasy, for example, use "job", while NetHack always calls them roles.

rawPage:
{{languages}} When starting ''[[NetHack]]'', the game asks for the '''role''' you want to play, with the option of letting the game randomly pick one. You can also set the role in your [[nethackrc]] file, or specify it on the command line with the -p option. Each role begins with different starting equipment and different levels of mastery in weapons. Intrinsics that are gained when leveling up (such as a [[Ranger]]'s intrinsic stealth) and conducts (such as the [[Monk]]'s vegetarian conducts) also vary with each role. Experienced players often attempt to ascend all thirteen roles. Some roles are considered more [[Role difficulty|difficult]] to ascend than others. See [[role difficulty]] for more details. == Role table by starting attributes and intrinsics == The following contains the mean and [[wikipedia:standard deviation|standard deviation]] of the starting [[attribute]]s; the initial intrinsics; and the intrinsics gained at specific [[experience level]]s, for various roles played as [[Human (starting race)|humans]]. The means and standard deviations were found by simulation; the simulation source code can found on the talk page.[[Talk:Role#Initial attribute simulation code]] Note that non-human races may have different mean attributes due to attribute maximums, especially if the maximum for an attribute is less than approximately one or two standard deviations above the human mean. {| class="prettytable" |- ! !
